intro: Takulumena camargoi, commonly known as the Camargue thistle, is a perennial plant native to the wetlands of the Camargue region in southern France. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped, hairy leaves that are often covered in a waxy coating. Its flowers bloom in late summer, producing yellow to orange inflorescences that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant thrives in moist, saline soils and is adapted to the unique ecological conditions of its native habitat.
